awd_titl_txt: Nanometer-Scale Piezoelectric, Flexoelectric and Piezotronic Effects from 2D Piezoelectric Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Piezoelectricity and flexoelectricity describe a response of electricity to uniform and non-uniform mechanical strains, respectively. Both effects play an important role in modern electromechanical systems, including energy harvesters, power transformers, sensors, microbalances, transducers, and actuators. This project aims to experimentally test the theoretical prediction that both effects may exhibit orders of magnitudes enhancement in very thin, on the order of 1 to 2 nanometer scale, films. Studies are conducted on a two-dimensional (2D) sheet-like oxide materials. In such materials, strain can impose tremendous impacts on their properties. This project aims to study how electron movement in such 2D material systems can be controlled by the strain. The knowledge gained from this research has the potential to disclose new materials and design principles for next-generation sensors, actuators, and energy harvesting devices. This project provides opportunities for recruiting and training graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented minority groups with knowledge and experiences of synthesizing and characterizing 2D oxide nanomaterials on the frontier of nanoscience. The research results are utilized in outreach  to high school teachers and students. This project also creates open-access online codes for calculating the piezotronic band diagrams, serving the international communities of piezoelectrics, semiconductors and piezotronics.

Technical Description: Atomistic calculations have predicted an orders-of-magnitude enhancement of the piezoelectric and flexoelectric effects in nanometer-thick free-standing two-dimensional (2D) materials. This strong strain-induced polarization may drastically influence their semiconductor properties via the piezotronic effect. However, due to the lack of appropriate material objects, experimental study of the nanometer-scale piezoelectric and flexoelectric effects far lags behind the theoretical study. Free-standing nanometer-thick single-crystalline ZnO nanosheets recently created by the PI's team offer a unique platform for studying the piezoelectric, flexoelectric and piezotronic behavior of this material. The research aims at studying these phenomena in 2D ZnO nanosheets in order to verify the theoretical prediction of the gigantic enhancement of both effects in the nanometer scale and to understand how the semiconductor properties are tuned by the strain-induced polarization in 2D nanomaterial systems. Atomic force microscopy-based techniques, including Kelvin probe microscopy, electrostatic force microscopy, and piezoelectric force microscopy applied on individually strained ZnO nanosheets allow quantitative estimation of piezoelectric and flexoelectric coefficients along different crystal orientations. In addition, the strain-related interfacial electron energetics and electronic transport properties in 2D confined piezoelectric and semiconducting channels are explored by designing and characterizing ZnO nanosheet-based transistors and diodes.

por.por_cntn:
In this research project, we studied the predicted large-enhancement of piezoelectric and flexoelectric effects in nanometer-thick ZnO nanosheets, obtained a comprehensive understanding of how the electronic properties are tuned by thickness, defects, and strain-induced polarization in this two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterial systems.

We synthesized piezoelectric single-crystalline ZnO nanosheets with different thickness at the water-air interface through the ionic layer epitaxy (ILE) technique. The as-synthesized nanosheets are free-standing and can be transferred onto any substrates. We demonstrated the in-situ X-ray characterization to investigate the mechanism of the ILE nanosheet growth and obtained a comprehensive understanding of the crystal structure evolution in the nanosheets, which offered a guide for manipulating nanosheet structures with different surface coating molecules and defects.

We fabricated transistor with ZnO nanosheets and found the memristive behavior of ZnO nanosheet heterojunction and the conduction mechanism of the semiconducting ZnO 2D confined channels. In addition, we discovered strong ferromagnetism in ZnO nanosheets by introducing massive H-passivated Zn vacancy concentration during synthesis. This may eventually lead to a new class of high saturation moment magnetic semiconducting oxide materials that hold great promise for 2D spintronic and other magnetic applications.

We developed a method for electrostatic free PFM to achieve accurate piezoelectric polarization of ZnO-nanosheets of various thicknesses. The thickness dependent piezoelectric response of nanometer-thick ZnO illustrated an overall greater piezocoefficient when compared to bulk counterpart, which ranged in 10-60pm/V for thicknesses of 1-4nm. We fabricated piezotronic transistor of ZnO nanosheets supported on flexible substrates and studied the influences of strain-induced electric polarization on the charge transport behavior in the semiconducting ZnO 2D confined channels. We observed an apparent linear increase in the measured piezoelectric coefficient for the given thickness regime under compressive and tensile strained conditions. The enhanced piezoelectric coefficient is due to a unit cell dependency that leads to a change in the relative dipole moment produced by Zn2+ cations and O2- anions and the applied uniaxial strain of the ZnO nanosheets. Our development of strain-gated ZnO piezotronic transistors supported on flexible human-compatible substrates may bring unprecedented application potentials toward wearable electronic devices.

We also developed a piezotronic-modulated photoelectrochemical (PEC) system and found a versatile strategy to enhance of solar energy converting performance, that the effective charge collection requires high conductivity, but a maximal ferroelectric/piezoelectric polarization require the material to be insulating. This is also principally works for any PEC electrodes, ranging from oxides to Si and III-IV composites. We also programed Mathematica codes into an open-access tool for calculating the piezotronic band diagrams, serving the international communities of piezoelectrics, semiconductors and piezotronics.

Through this project, we developed kinetically stabilized, non-equilibrium, highly defective 2D nanomaterials with significantly exotic electronic and magnetic properties not attainable in the conventional bulk form. Our development of experimental quantification of the piezoelectric and flexoelectric coefficients in nanometer-sized crystals provided valuable insights into the nanometer scale piezoelectric and flexoelectric effects. This project rendered transformative knowledge on the nanoscale electromechanical coupling effects in 2D-confined material systems, bringing unprecedented application potentials toward next-generation sensors, actuators, and nanogenerators using advanced 2D piezoelectric nanomaterial building blocks.

This research trained graduate and undergraduate students with knowledge and experiences of synthesizing and characterizing 2D oxide nanomaterials on the frontier of nanoscience. The fundamental understanding obtained from this project has been integrated in my graduate course of Nanomaterials and Nanotechnology. The knowledge was disseminated to the pubic via teaching and learning programs of UW-Madison such as science fairs.
